segments.text: I think he is the one who engineered the split between Joe and Bridges, and I don't remember what the final thing was over.
Could it have been your nomination to represent the CIO Maritime Committee here in Washington?
I don't think it could have been.
It may have been, but I don't think it could have been.
Because I was working under Bridges Bjorn Holling, who was the executive secretary.
I was working under him.
And they called him back to San Francisco because they had something there that they thought he could be more effective in than what he was doing here.
And that's when I was named as secretary to succeed to head up the committee.
This could have been, although I don't know.
I'm sure I had a lot of people around who didn't like me.
And some of them I know didn't like me because they thought I was too close to Joe.
We were very close personal friends, no question about it.
During your years as a lobbyist, we'll use that term, here in Washington, who were some congressmen who were favorable to you, who was the NMU's friends?
What was the relationship with Vic Marcantonio?
Marcantonio?
He would do almost anything he could that we would ask him to do.
Just thinking about it, I would say that after I was here for maybe a year and a half or two years,
that most of the congressmen that we contacted on maritime matters became friends of the Union.
And maybe I'm bragging a little, but let me tell you, and you be the judge of what you think.
I had certain basic principles which I followed.
And I made no bones of those, and incidentally,
I can tell you that they didn't always agree with Bridges, and we clashed over them several times.
First of all, I took the position that whatever was good for the United States was good for the merchant marine, not the other way around.
I also took the position that the companies who operated those ships
were good for the merchant marine as long as they carried out programs that would help to make the merchant marine grow and help serve the national policy.
I took the position that these people furnished jobs for seamen and longshoremen.
It was damn time that we learned that and stopped calling them the bosses and start cooperating with them.
I and the communists clashed many times over this.
Matter of fact, I wrote a guest column for Joe once while he was away somewhere.
I don't know where now, but he asked me to write it.
And I wrote about cooperation.
In the next issue of the pilot, Ferdinand Smith wrote an article attacking that.
It was a party article done by someone in the, probably in the then Daily Worker.
for him, but it was so patent that it was a party line attack that you couldn't mistake it for anything.
Anyway, they were against cooperating with those goddamn ship owners, you know, this sort of crap.
Do you think this perception by Curran and parts of the Union anyway, as far as the need to cooperate with ship owners and with the government, comes only after the beginning of the Second World War?
Yes, it was not possible before.
No way.
No way.
Because all seamen hated ship owners.
It didn't have to be a communist to hate a ship owner, I can guarantee you.
because the conditions were so poor.
I mean, they were rotten on ships, really.
I remember the first ship I was on, no, the second ship I was on, the second engineer at lunch one day said, my God, looky here, looky here.
And he took his spoon and dipped something out of his soup and got up and walked around and put it in front of the captain.
Look at that.
I found that in my soup.
Captain said, oh, that's only a half of a cockroach.
Went on eating his soup.
Well, I started to tell you why I thought we built up good relations with congressmen.
I always tried to know my facts when I was talking to them.
And I always tried to leave them a paper.
on what we were talking about, what I was seeking.
And if there were other alternatives, I tried to present those alternatives.
And if there were specific dangers to them individually, I always presented those.
In other words, I never tried to sell a congressman something that I wouldn't want another guy to sell me if I were in his shoes.
I tried to play the golden rule with them, in other words.
Do to them as I would want somebody to do to me.
And I think that took part, had a part in building up relationships with the congressmen.
I can say up until about 1970,
or maybe a little before that, 68.
I don't remember the date.
But Joe Curran had an extremely good reputation here in Washington.
And unfortunately, that reputation started to wane when he sent his son down here.
I don't know whether 68, 69, or 70.
Tal can give you the date on that.
And his son started screwing things up for good.
For example, one of the first things he did was put out a press release attacking Senator Magnuson.
Well, Senator Magnuson wouldn't do any damn thing that we asked him to do.
That little bastard came in here, and this was one of the first things that he did.
And this started knocking Joe's, well,
Now, before that, his reputation started to get knocked down by Bill Perry.
Perry had developed a habit of calling me on the phone and telling me what Joe wanted done.
Then he would call the person I would go to in the government and tell that person they'd better goddamn sure get this done before I even go to the person, tell them.
And this started breaking down the relations of the, you know, the reputation of the NMU.
What about the Taft-Hartley Act?
How involved were you in fighting that?
Let me go back a minute, but bring me back to Taft-Hartley.
Talking about the congressman.
Trying to think of who reminded me of that just recently.
Anyway, myself and this person walked into a meeting of the House Merchant Marine Fisheries Committee when Herbert Bonner was chairman.
We walked in after I'd been away about six weeks on a trip.
I came back, and we walked in together.
And Bonner got up and said, now, wait a minute.
I don't know who was testifying.
Stop right here.
Someone just walked in the room I want you to know about.
Hoyt Haddock just came in.
If we have one annoying thing about the merchant marine, he's the man to ask.
So he took that guy off the stand.
I wasn't prepared to testify.
And I said, I want to ask him some questions about this.
And so he did, went on.
But I mention that only because it's indicative of the fact that
I had built up a personal trust with these people.
I tried to do it, and I was successful.

And I remember another situation where an attorney who happened to be an ex-Congressman, the only Congressman that Roosevelt purged, if you ever read anything about him trying to purge some of the Congressmen, that was the only Congressman that was ever purged, and he was a New York Congressman.
practicing law here, I had testified on some bill the day before.
And he came in the next day and was trying to knock down my testimony by sarcastic references to me and my testimony.
And the ranking Republican at that time, Thor Tollefson, after listening to it for a while, he said, now wait.
I want you to know that as far as I'm concerned, Hoyt Haddock is a personal friend of mine.
And he said, we're not holding a hearing here on the character of Hoyt Haddock, unfortunately.
If we were, I would be the first witness for him.
But we're holding a hearing on such and such.
And you haven't told us one thing about this bill that we're considering at all.
All you've done is sit here and attack Hoyt Haddock.
He said, I'm personally tired of it.
And if you continue to testify, I'm getting up and leave, because I don't intend to sit here any longer.
And Bonner was still chairman then.
And Bonner said, and I couldn't agree more.
He said, I'm telling you now, if that's the rest of your testimony, you're finished.
I'm perfectly content to go ahead and listen to you if you have something constructive to say.
The guy got up and left.
He didn't have anything constructive to say.
But I only...
I don't think I'm egotistical in saying those, because I literally set out to build that kind of relationship with people that I had to work with.
And I had that kind of relationship with all of them.
For example, Senator Magnuson, after one of the elections, there were a number of changes on his committee.
Well, I was over the hearing one day, and...
Just before the hearing went up, I got up and went around to the back room where they held their executive meetings.
And I was sitting in there talking with some of the staff.
And he and some of them came in.
They were going to hold an executive session.
They decided that outside.
So he said, well, then we're going to hold our meeting here.
So when he said that, I got up and started to go out.
He said, no, Hoyt, don't leave.
I want you to stay, because I want these people to meet you and know about you.
So they had already decided who was going to be committee chairman.
And I remember a congressman from Florida, John, he replaced Claude Pepper.
I can't think of his name now.
John something was in charge of the land and inland transportation.
He said, I want all the committee to know that Hoyt Haddock, when there's anything doing with maritime, before I take a position on it, I find out what his position is.
And I normally follow whatever he suggests that I follow.
And then each one of the guys asked me, he said, will you
Give me the kind of help you give Magnuson.
I said, I'll give you all the help that I can.
That's what I'm paid to do.
I said, you must understand that when I give you my ideas on things, that they're only my ideas, and I have as much chance of being wrong as anyone else.
I said, when I talk to you about a subject, if you are better prepared on it than I, I consider you to have a better understanding than I.
If you're not,
I figured that you've got a 50% chance of being as right as me.
I said, that's the way I work.
That's the way I think.

And if you ask me a question, I will either tell you what my opinion is on it, how I think it should be handled, or I'll tell you that I don't know, but I will study it for you and give you an opinion.
And that's the way I operate.
Now, you ask me,
uh, how we got along with the congressman.
That's the way we got along with them.
And we got along with the administrative people the same way.
For example, if we had a bill that we wanted to get through, I didn't start working with the Congress on that bill.
I started working with the administration and I would get the appropriate administrative agencies that were concerned that I knew that this bill was going to be referred to for reports
I would talk to them before we proceed with that.

Then I would go get, after I would talk with them, I would go talk to the budget department and tell them the position, our position, and the fact that I discussed this with the various agencies and what their position was.
Then I would come to Congress.
But that's the way I operated, and I think we had built up a good relationship.
What about the Taft-Hartley?
Well, before the Taft-Hartley, I had testified on the National Labor Relations Act.
I told them that I thought it was a bad act.
I said it's going to help labor for a while, but it's then going to become the enemy of labor, just like all government agencies.
Because you have to understand that government agencies are controlled by the bankers of this country.
I said, any congressman who is honest knows that.
And if he doesn't know it, he's a damn fool.
So I had that record.
And when I came to the Taft-Hartley, of course, the whole labor movement worked on Taft-Hartley.
And in the Senate, I don't think I testified on Taft-Hartley in the House.
I testified in the Senate and Taft was chairman of the committee at the time.
I guess that meant that the Republicans were in power in the Congress at the time.
I don't know what year this was.
Boiling it all down.
I have never seen any member, any person testify for Taft who was treated so nice as I was by him.
I expected him to cut my throat from ear to ear.
But literally he was, he couldn't have been nicer if I were a king visiting his home for the first time as a personal friend.
I never understood it.
Still don't understand it.
But that's the way he treated me.
Maybe he's trying to kill me with kindness.
I don't know.
But he gave everyone a hard time coming before that committee, except me.
I mean literally.
And representatives of labor here in Washington talked about that for at least a year afterwards.
The way he was deferent to me.
I don't know why, but he was.
There was one other situation we were talking about.
This was also a labor bill.
They were having hearings on withholding taxes.
And they wanted to have withholding taxes for merchant seamen because of their room and board.
You weren't here then, were you, Tal?
You were?
Anyway, there was a fellow from the electrical workers.
What the hell was his name?
Well, he'd been a professor at one of the universities in New York.
I don't remember his name now.
I can't think of it.
Who had prepared a tremendous brief on this.
Anyway, I went before him and talked about this position of taxing seamen's wages and so forth.
And all of the committee were agreeing with me on it.
My approach to it was correct because this fitted the situation that they confronted in their whole house.
My basic position was that it didn't reduce the cost of a merchant seaman rent that he had to pay because he went to sea.
And it only reduced his grocery bill very insignificantly at all when he wasn't at home.
because his wife, if she had any kids, she had to feed those, and she probably bought about the same amount of food anyway.
You know, the congressman said, this is the same situation that confronts us.
The chairman says, I have a home in Washington State, and I have one here.
And it don't reduce my expenses when I leave out there.
As a matter of fact, it increases them because I come here.
But I can readily see, even if I didn't have a home here,
I still have to maintain the home out there.
It's not going to cost me any less.
And they were agreeing with me.
And this fellow followed me.
And he had a very well-prepared statement.
I mean, it was the kind of a statement I would like to have had when I talked to him.
But I didn't have it, because I didn't prepare a statement.
I added it up to him.
And they started attacking him from the moment he sat down there.
But the problem was he was talking down to them.
He was educating them as though they were children.
And they felt this right away.
And they just gave him a hell of a time.
And he really had a statement that could have convinced anyone.
But he just lost everything.
But I mention that because I don't know.
It's the way you approach people, I guess.
It's the only thing I can say.
Now, on talking about Taft-Hartley, I don't to this day know why Taft treated me like he did.
I literally thought he was going to give me hell.
What about moving backwards a ways to the, right after the war, the threatened,
24-hour strike at the end of Utah had.
Who was the catalyst behind this?
Was this the 40-hour week strike?
The strike after the war for wages.
For wages.
Well, this could have been the 40-hour week strike.
I don't know.
I'm afraid the AFL-CIO Maritime Committee was, because this was part of our
Part of the program that I put together, you know, try to get the unions to recognize what was coming.
If it was the 40-hour week strike, the catalyst was the then head of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
I don't know what the name of it was then, but the fellow who was the head of it was a Tammany politician.
And he had told his ship owners, don't worry, there's not going to be a strike.
Well, Franklin called me up and asked me, he said,
What the hell was that guy's name?
He was president of their committee, whatever they called it, and in charge of labor relations.
I said, don't you believe him, Jack.
There's going to be a strike on the 40-hour week unless he gives in on it.
So OK.
He went back to the meeting next day and told them that there was going to be a strike.
And this guy said, no, not going to be any strike.
They're not going to push this 40-hour week.
He called me again and told me.
I said, Jack, I can only tell you what I know.
And right now, I know that there's going to be a strike unless the 40-hour week is granted.
And I said, if you don't grant it before the strike, you will grant it after, and it will cost you more money.
So they didn't grant it before the strike, and it did cost them more money.
In 51 and 52, was when Murray was beginning to talk about stepping down from the CIO before the AFL and the CIO emerged, was Joe Kern being groomed to become the president of the CIO?
Not to my knowledge.
Not to my knowledge.
How close was his working relationship with Philip Murray?
I don't think as close as many others.
Philip Murray's closest working relationships were with the steelworkers, whoever was in the steelworkers.
Many of his people came out of the steelworker organization into the CIO as a result.
But I don't think Joe had any particular in with Murray.
I think any good honest person had an in with Murray.
Murray was a very simple person.
If you believed in what you were trying to do and tried to do a good job, you didn't have to do a good job.
But if you really tried to, Murray had respect for you.
With Joe's heart attack in 52.
His what?
Heart attack.
I don't remember when it was.
Why did he step down then?
Why?
Why didn't he?
As I understand, it was a fairly massive heart attack, wasn't it?
It was.
Yeah, he was out for a long time.
Well, he talked about retiring.
Whether he ever meant it or not, I don't know.
I think most everyone encouraged him not to retire unless he really had to.
I know that I did.
I know that Headley Stone did.
Trying to think of who else was there at the time.
I just don't remember who else was there.
Now outside of the NMU, I don't know who talked to him about it.
Franklin may have.
He and Franklin became good friends too.
You know, they respected each other.
Franklin respected his word and he respected Franklin's word.
So by the 50s then, you'd be correct to generalize that the NMU had a
a good working relationship with at least most of the steamship owners?
Yes.
The old antagonist, protagonist days of the 30s were over by then.
That's right, I think so.
And they were cooperative.
We had gotten away from what we call the ship actions by then.
You know, where you set down one ship over one issue, whether it was in the contract or not.
In other words, the crew takes action.
What happened with the passenger ships?
Apparently it was one of Germany's biggest defeats.
Well, they got to the point where they were so overmanned and so much corruption existed on them that they weren't making any money for the companies.
Had this been verified by the union?
passenger ships were indeed losing money?
Oh yes, oh yes.

And the government was tired of paying subsidies to them because the subsidies were so big and they really weren't contributing anything to the commerce of the United States in terms of commerce, just carrying passengers for pleasure.
The Union worked out several
new passenger scales, you know, to scale them down.

But there was great resistance towards lowering the scale on the passenger ships because the seamen had become, this time, had gotten to the position where the old trade union principles really didn't exist anymore.
You know, at one time,
to become a good trade unionist, you had to be a good worker.
You had to be a competent worker in the craft that you were following.
And they had gotten it this time, where that was immaterial.
What do you think caused that, this change in mentality of the average seaman?
I think the union provided too much protection for them.
They didn't rely upon their own abilities any longer.
They started relying solely upon the Union, just like the situation now.
Too many people rely upon the United States government.
They have no idea of being productive citizens, of looking out for themselves.
They want Uncle Sam to look out for them.
And I think it's that same mentality that Seaman wanted the Union to look out for them, not themselves.
Well, you can't keep a union strong with that kind of mentality.
What about William Perry?
The what?
William Perry.
There isn't anything good I can say about the man.
When was he first brought into the union?
I don't remember the year.
Well.
It was just before this convention where this fight took place.
What was the man's name that Joe tangled with?
Joe Stack?
Joe Stack.
Joe Stack fired William Perry.
And William Perry came to Joe and asked Joe to put him back on a job somewhere.
I don't know what the discussion was, because I was in Washington at that time, I think.
I'm sure I was.
Anyway, Joe put him back on.
Joe was a very soft-hearted guy.
He would do anything for you.
Really, he would.
He was egotistical like all of us, but he did have a very soft heart.
Well, hell, if I would go to him and say, Joe, I want to go to bed with your wife, Joe would say, all right.
He would walk out of the room.
I never tried this, but I'm telling you that that's the kind of a guy he was.
If you were his friend, anything that he had was yours.
And anything that he wanted from me, he could get, no question about that.
But that's one of the things.
And William Perry did everything to build his ego.
For example, it got to the point where Joe wouldn't buy a suit without William Perry passing on it.
Joe didn't get married the second time without William Perry passing on it.
He had that much influence on Joe.
Was Perry like a father-son relationship or a relationship of equals?
He envisioned Perry as a son that he wished Joe Paul could be.
I think that was where the real problem was.
In other words, Perry was an able guy in his own way, and he could convince Joe of almost anything.
And you know, like Joe Paul, Joe Paul decided he wanted to come to Washington, be a legislative representative.
Joe sent him down here, become legislative representative.
Joe Paul perceived his job here as telling me what to do and how to do it.
I tried to tell him that this wasn't the right way to do it, and he would go ahead and do it anyway.
And you couldn't touch Joe on Joe Paul at all.
For example, Joe Paul, is this on?
Well, it doesn't make any difference.
No, take it off.
Perry was replacing what Joe was missing.
And you could say anything against Perry and Joe wouldn't believe you.
In your opinion, what do you think Joe Curran's greatest contributions to maritime labor and to merchant seamen were?
And what were his greatest victories?
I guess the greatest victory was starting the Union.
Really, that was the greatest thing he ever did.
And then keeping it to grow was just all adding to it.
Did he ever talk to you about what he considered to be his greatest achievement?
Would he ever reminisce about something like that?
Oh, we would talk about specific issues, you know, as they would happen and maybe go back to
some of the issues and discuss them, but I don't think he ever perceived that any one thing was...
He was more proud of than another?
What?
That he was more proud of than another?
No, I don't think so.
I think he was just proud of the whole thing.
What do you think were his greatest feelings?
His greatest value was leadership, personal leadership.
What would you say his greatest failures were?
I guess his egotism was his greatest failure.
For example, letting a guy like Perry lead him around by the nose.
And I mean he literally did it.
For example, they had a problem on the Americans.
I think maybe it involved an electrician.
Doesn't matter.
I don't remember the details of it.
But anyway, it involved one man.
The company had disciplined him, and the union wanted the man put back.
And they tied up the ship.
But before they did this, Perry called me and said, Joe has decided to

tie up the america what do you think i said i don't think it's a good idea perry and i wish joe would call me and talk to me because i think it's very important that he know the facts knows the facts the u.s lines has worked out a deal with a greek steamship company to buy the america
And I think that anything that you do now is going to deliver that ship from the American flag to the Greek flag.
Oh, don't worry, I'll tell Joe.
Well, he didn't tell Joe.
Anyway, Joe asked me to come to New York on the day that they were supposed to meet for arbitration on the issue.
This was after they had the ship tied up.
I told Joe of all of this, what I told Perry.
And he said to Bill, why in the hell didn't you tell me this?
I didn't tell you because I didn't believe it was so, and I still don't believe it's so.
And Joe says, well, I can damn sure check it, and you know I can check it.
Well, go ahead and check it.
So Joe went and called Franklin, asked him,
I understand that you have a Greek ship owner who wants to buy the America and you're ready to sell it to him.
Is it so?
I said, yes, that's so.
Frankly, I wouldn't lie to him.
He just told him the truth.
So Joe said, thank you.
And he came back and said, you little son of a bitch ought to kick your ass right out of here.
And then five minutes later, he forgot about it, I guess.
Anyway, I said, I think you're wasting time on the arbitration.
The company's not going to agree to do what you want to do on this man.
They want you to force them to sell into a situation where they can sell America.
You better back out of this.
Joe said, I don't see how I can.
I think we have to go ahead with the arbitration.
I said, if you go ahead with the arbitration, are you going to accept the decision?
Not if it's against us.
I said, well, Joe, don't go ahead with it.
It's going to be against you, believe me.
Well, they went ahead with it, and sure enough, it was against them.
The ship was sold to the Greek.
What about the Kieran-Paul Hall relationship?
Well, you have to understand the origin, I guess, of the SIU to realize that.
And I've told you already that this was the shipowner's answer to the National Maritime Union.
And...
Were there ever any attempts for the two unions to fuse?
There has always been good, honest attempts on the part of the National Maritime Union to put the seamen's unions together.
And Joe, when he was leader, was 100% open to this.
Shannon Wall, who is now president, is 100% open to it.
And they've both worked for it.
But there has never wanted, the SIU has never wanted to put the unions together.
That's why they have never been wanted, they have never been put together.
Now, why Hall didn't want them together, I don't know.
For example, about, trying to think of the year.
Maybe about 1953 or 4 or 5 in there somewhere.
There was a meeting of the unions out in the maritime unions over some issue.
I don't know what the issue was either.
Out in Cincinnati under the chairmanship of the then president of the Railway Clerks Organization.
And Joe asked me to go out there to the meeting with him.
I did go out and after the meeting I stayed overnight because I couldn't get a plane back to Washington that night and Joe went on to New York.
Paul stayed there.
I don't know the reason.
He was probably coming to Washington too.
I don't remember now.
But anyway, I sat down with him and talked with him about the merger for a long time.
And I said, Paul is it
a question of leadership that's keeping you from wanting a merger?
He said, no, I want a merger.
It's Joe Kern keeping the merger apart.
I said, Paul, you're not talking to a kid now.
I said, I've been in this organization business for some time, and I've been a personal friend of Joe Kern's ever since he hit the bricks in New York.
So don't tell me about Joe Kern.
I know about Joe Kern.
I want to know about Joe.
I said, if it's a question of you becoming president of the organization, tell me.
It can be worked out.
He said, what do you mean it can be worked out?
That can't be worked out.
Joe wouldn't go for anything like that.
I said, Paul, if you want a merger, I will tell you now that you can have a merger of the SIU and the NMU.
with Joe Kern being made as president for six months.
And at the end of that six months, you're taking over as president.
I said, would that give you any problem?
He said, no, that wouldn't give me any problem.
I said, well, what's the problem?
I never did get an answer to what the problem was.
But there was never any merger as long as Paul Hall was alive.
But Joe was ready to step aside at any time there was a merger.
At that time, he wanted to retire.
This was in the 50s after his heart attack?
This was in the 50s.
Speaking of retirement, why did, in your opinion, did Joe Kern stay on as union president until 1973?
And when he did retire, did he consult with you?
Yes, he did.
I think he didn't retire because he didn't think he had built
anyone who was capable of taking over, and he hadn't.
And he recognized this as a big shortcoming on his part.
So he wanted to try to get someone who was capable of taking over.
So he waited that long.
He had had plans then to retire much earlier.
Yes, he had.
He had wanted to retire for some time.
I said the middle of the 50s.
You know, this could have been the middle of the 60s, just as well as the 50s.
I just don't remember dates.
There's no way I can do it.
The only way I can remember is the Cincinnati meeting, whenever it took place.
Well, it would have to have been before the merger.
When was the merger?
No.
I believe it was 55, wasn't it?
It starts and talks in 52 and 53.
Well, it was before the merger.
No, it was after the merger because the railway clerk's guy was an AFL guy.
It had to be after the merger.
Well, whenever it was anyway.
But Joe wanted to retire at that time.
And he told me specifically that he would like to put the merger together and if it meant for him not being an officer in the merger, he would do it.
but he would also like very much to be the first president of that merged organization.
You know, he wanted that very badly and made no bones about it, but he said, I'm willing to step aside from that if it can't be accomplished without it.
I never recommended but one person to Joe Curran in my life, and that happened to be Shannon Wall.
I'd met Shannon Wall at a CIO convention held in Los Angeles.
Shannon was agent at the San Diego Hall for the NMU.
And I told Joe of my meeting with him, my having meals with him a couple of times and talking with him about problems.
I said, of all of the agents, Joe, that you've ever had,
In my opinion, this is the best organized individual of any of them, understands more clearly what the issues are than any of them, and has the greater facility of talking about those problems.
The next election, he was put on the slate by Joe
I guess it was vice president.
I'm not sure now whether it was vice president or secretary-treasurer.
Anyway, it was brought to the national office.
It was not, it was not, it was not secretary-treasurer because that came up later.
Joe was going to name a fellow by the name of Mel Baricic as secretary-treasurer.
I said, Joe,
Do you realize that this man can't write a letter?
And he knows nothing about keeping books.
Has no grasp of either one of these issues.
This is going to mean that he's got to hire someone to do all this for him.
I said, I'm not opposed to that.
But he's got to be able to make a determination about what someone does for him, whether it's right or not.
Joe says, you're right.
So he changed that and brought Shannon.
